dublin_core.dcvalue: In the United States a nationwide Commercial Mobile Alert Service CMAS is being planned to alert cellular mobile device subscribers to emergencies occurring near the location of the mobile device The plan specifies a unique audio attention signal as well as a unique vibration attention signal for mobile devices set to vibrate to identify that the incoming message pertains to an emergency Ratings of vibration signals of varying lengths and patterns were obtained from 44 deaf users of mobile devices for the perceived effectiveness of the signal in getting their attention in an emergency situation Longer signals received higher ratings than shorter ones and three signals with temporal on off patterns were rated significantly better than a constant vibration The U S government s recommended vibration signal for the CMAS an important feature for access to emergency alerts by deaf persons is supported by the results of the study
Journal of deaf studies and deaf education
Vibration signaling in mobile devices for emergency alerting: a study with deaf evaluators.
